author: Jean-Paul Sartre
quote: Never believe that anti-Semites are completely unaware of the absurdity of their replies. They know that their remarks are frivolous, open to challenge. But they are amusing themselves, for it is their adversary who is obliged to use words responsibly, since he believes in words. The anti-Semites have the right to play. They even like to play with discourse for, by giving ridiculous reasons, they discredit the seriousness of their interlocutors. They delight in acting in bad faith, since they seek not to persuade by sound argument but to intimidate and disconcert. If you press them too closely, they will abruptly fall silent, loftily indicating by some phrase that the time for argument is past.

author: Quincy Jones
quote: God walks out of the room when you’re thinking about money.

author: Paul Krugman
quote: This will end badly, and the sooner it does, the better.

author: Winston Churchill
quote: Out of intense complexities intense simplicities emerge.

author: William Gibson
quote: That which is overdesigned, too highly specific, anticipates outcome; the anticipation of outcome guarantees, if not failure, the absence of grace.

author: Brian Eno
quote: ...not doing the thing that nobody had ever thought of not doing.

author: Christiaan Huygens
quote: The world is my country, science is my religion.

author: Harry S. Truman
quote: Machines are ahead of morals by some centuries, and when morals catch up perhaps there’ll be no reason for any of it.

author: Chris Hedges
quote: Once we sign on for war’s crusade, once we see ourselves on the side of the angels, once we embrace a theological or ideological belief system that defines itself as the embodiment of goodness and light, it is only a matter of how we will carry out murder.
work: War Is A Force That Gives Us Meaning

author: Chris Hedges
quote: Modern war is directed primarily against civilians. Look at Kosova, Bosnia, Rwanda, Vietnam, or World War II. And nuclear terrorism is the logical outcome of modern industrial warfare.
work: War Is A Force That Gives Us Meaning

author: Chris Hedges
quote: The danger is not that fundamentalism will grow so much as that modern, secular society will wither.
work: War Is A Force That Gives Us Meaning

author: Chris Hedges
quote: Love, when it is deep and sustained by two individuals, includes self-giving — often self-sacrifice — as well as desire. For the covenant of love is such that it recognizes both the fragility and the sanctity of the individual. It recognizes itself in the other. It alone can save us.
work: War Is A Force That Gives Us Meaning

author: Karen Armstrong
quote: Calvinist theologies of election have been largely instrumental in encouraging Americans to believe that they are God’s own nation. As in Josiah’s Kingdom of Judah, such a belief is likely to flourish at a time of political insecurity when people are haunted by the fear of their own destruction.

author: David Milch, et al.
quote: I know we are as much in the world in our pain as in our happiness.

author: J. R. R. Tolkien
quote: “Say also,” said Gandalf, “that to crooked eyes truth may wear a wry face.”

author: J. R. R. Tolkien
quote: “Perilous to us all are the devices of an art deeper than we possess ourselves.”

author: J. R. R. Tolkien
quote: Be bold, but wary! Keep up your merry hearts, and ride to meet your fortune!

author: J. R. R. Tolkien
quote: It was Sam’s first view of a battle of Men against Men, and he did not like it much. He was glad that he could not see the dead face. He wondered what the man’s name was and where he came from; and if he was really evil of heart, of what lies or threats had led him on the long march from his home; and if he would not really rather have stayed there in peace.

author: James Madison
quote: The means of defense against foreign danger historically have become the instruments of tyranny at home.

author: Simon Cozens
quote: Mathematics, logic, science: they’re useful servants, but exceptionally bad masters.

author: Learned Hand
quote: Our dangers, as it seems to me, are not from the outrageous but from the conforming; not from those who rarely and under the lurid glare of obloquy upset our moral complaisance, or shock us with unaccustomed conduct, but from those, the mass of us, who take their virtues and tastes, like their shirts and their furniture, from the limited patterns which the market offers.

author: John Ashcroft
quote: “There was maybe 10 days or close to two weeks ago an uncorroborated report of undetermined reliability about natural gas,” Mr. Ashcroft said at a news conference. “Frankly, those are the kinds of reports which we take seriously.”

author: John von Neumann
quote: Anyone who considers arithmetical methods of producing random digits is, of course, in a state of sin.
work: Various Techniques Used In Connection With Random Digits

author: Sir Herbert Robert Beerbohm Tree
quote: Sirs, I have tested your machine. It adds a new terror to life and makes death a long-felt want.

author: Benjamin Franklin
quote: Behold the rain which descends from heaven upon our vineyards, and which incorporates itself with the grapes to be changed into wine; a constant proof that God loves us, and loves to see us happy!

author: Douglas Adams
quote: How can I tell that the past isn’t a fiction designed to account for the discrepancy between my immediate physical sensations and my state of mind?
work: The More Than Complete Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy

author: Christopher Morley
quote: Energy is not endless. Better hoard it for your own work. Be intangible and hard to catch; be secret and proud and inwardly uncomfortable. Say yes and don’t mean it; pretend to agree; dodge every kind of organization, and evade, elude, recede. Be about your own affairs as you would also forbear from others at theirs, and thereby show your respect for the holiest ghost we know, the creative imagination.

author: Catherine Liu
quote: They didn’t want what I wanted from them. They were confused by my insistence. I’ll never be able to tell them how hurt I was, how betrayed I felt. I’ll never be able to tell them that they broke my heart, but in all the wrong places.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
quote: Il semble que la perfection soit atteinte non quand il n'y a plus rien à ajouter, mais quand il n'y a plus rien à retrancher.

author: Fred Brooks
quote: Conceptual integrity. A clean, elegant programming product must present to each of its users a coherent mental model of the application, of strategies for doing the application, and of the user-interface tactics to be used in specifying actions and parameters. The conceptual integrity of the product, as perceived by the user, is the most important factor in ease of use.

author: John Cage
quote: I can’t understand why people are frightened of new ideas. I’m frightened of the old ones.
work: Conversing With Cage, by Richard Kostelanetz

author: Henry Rollins
quote: I left my hometown like a guy making a jail break.

author: Edwin Schlossberg
quote: The skill of writing is to create a context in which other people can think.

author: Douglas R. Hofstadter
quote: How can anyone fascinated by creativity and beauty fail to see in computers the ultimate tool for exploring their essence? Such ideas are the inner fire that propels my research and my writings.

author: Richard Rhodes
quote: Speech is a clumsiness and writing an impoverishment. Not language but the surface of the body is the child’s first map of the world, undifferentiated between subject and object, coextensive with the world it maps until awakening consciousness divides it off.
work: The Making of the Atomic Bomb

author: Lyndsey Gallant
quote: Your anger is the part of you that knows your mistreatment and abuse are unacceptable. Your anger knows you deserve to be treated well, and with kindness. Your anger is a part of you that loves you.
